Selective Electroreduction of CO2 toward Ethylene on Nano Dendritic Copper Catalysts at High Current Density
Christian Reller,* Ralf Krause, Elena Volkova, Bernhard Schmid, Sebastian Neubauer, Andreas Rucki, Manfred Schuster, and Günter Schmid
Dr. C. Reller, Dr. R. Krause, E. Volkova, B. Schmid, S. Neubauer, Dr. G. Schmid Siemens AG Erlangen, Günther-Scharowsky-Str.1 91058 Erlangen, Germany E-mail: Christian.Reller@Siemens.com Dr. A. Rucki, Dr. M. Schuster Siemens AG Munich, Otto Hahnring 1, 81739 Munich, Germany

these aspects, electrolysis also offers quick response times to variable loads to the corresponding current peaks within the network buffering. Calculations have shown that the resulting additional capital costs for conversion plants are to be borne only by a corresponding material value chain. The electrochemical production of chemical substances such as valuable ethylene and alcohols based on the waste product CO2 is therefore preferable toward the production of fuels (methane), since these are in strong price competition to cheap natural gas. The commercialization of the electrochemical production of
valuable chemical base products from CO2 strongly depends on the development of high performance electrocatalyst which could maintain high product selectivities at high current density. Former studies have demonstrated high Faradaic efficiencies (FEs) >90% for the production of formate at a high current density of 200 mA cm−2 by the use of gas diffusion electrodes (GDEs).[2,3] Moreover the Kenis group has recently published results for the electroreduction of CO2 toward ethylene at current densities up to 150 mA cm−2.[4] The development of Cu-based electro catalysts for the electrochemical conversion of CO2 was pursued since the 1970s and has been specially dominated by the works of Hori and Ogura.[5,6] The obtained product spectrum is mainly determined by the copper catalyst morphology and could generally be divided into gaseous products (CH4, C2H4, CO, H2) and liquid phase products like ethanol, n-propanol, formate, ethylene glycol, allylic alcohol, and acetate.[7–10] More over halogens in the electrolyte seem to increase the selectivity of the process toward ethylene. Nano structured catalysts such as Cu2O/ZnO have been identified by Irabien and co-workers to be capable of reducing CO2 toward methanol. The maximum CO2 conversion efficiency to liquidphase products was identified to be 54.8% and 31.4% for Cu2O and Cu2O/ZnO-based electrodes. Degradation effects of the material were found.[11,12] In their recent work, this group investigated in developing electrodes based on porous metal organic catalysts (HKUST-1, CuAdeAce, CuDTA, and CuZnDTA) for the electroreduction of CO2 toward alcohols.[13] Studies with single crystal Cu-electrodes have shown that the introduction of step sites to the Cu (100) basal plane leads to remarkably enhanced formation of C2H4. The product selectivity varied with the crystal orientation. The electro catalytic activity of C2H4 formation on Cu(S)-[n(100) × (111)] could further be activated by introduction of a certain amounts of step atoms. Crystal orientations
In situ deposited copper nanodendrites are herein proven to be a highly selective electrocatalyst which is capable of reducing CO2 to ethylene by reaching a Faradaic efficiency of 57% at a current density of 170 mA cm−2. It is found that the desired structures are formed in situ under acidic pH conditions at high electrode potentials more negative than −2 V versus Ag/AgCl. Detailed investigations on the preparation, characterization, and advancement of electrode materials and of the electrolyte have been performed. Catalyst degradation effects are intensively followed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) characterization methods and found to be a major root course for selectivity losses.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
As part of the expansion of renewable energies wind and solar energy, an increasing amount of electrical excess energy is available in the electricity grid. Regulation and commercial exploitation of the appearing excess energy provides particular challenges for the power- and chemical industry, simultaneously. A control and storage mechanism is therefore required which could equalize the delivered excess energy on relatively short time scales to make the energy provided usable. In order to lower the associated release of the greenhouse gas CO2, technologies are generally of interest, which can use CO2 as an inexpensive raw material for the production of fuels or chemicals. Therefore carbon capture and utilization concepts have been discussed, such as power-to-gas, where the temperature level is a key determinant of energy input.[1] These processes show several decisive disadvantages in terms of costs versus economic value and energy efficiency. The reduction of operational steps could further provide a balance of cost effectiveness and speed of response. The direct use of electricity instead of temperature offers a promising way to overcome these disadvantages within a direct single step electrolysis process. Beside

Cu (711) and Cu (511) showed an increased selectivity toward ethylene formation.[14] The square like arrangement of Cu atoms in Cu (100) terraces and presence of atomic steps have been proposed to favor CC bond coupling between the CHxO intermediates to give C2 compounds which was reported by Gattrell.[15] Up to date it is not well understood, which surface morphology or which structure and chemical composition of the catalyst is required to ensure a high ethylene selectivity at applicable current densities of several hundred mA cm−2. Mechanistic studies (operando spectroscopic studies) have provided the first evidence of reactive surface species (CO2−,·CH2) and the mechanism of formation of ethylene.[16,17] It is further unclear which pathways lead to the formation of alcohols such as ethanol, propanol, and methanol. According to nonaqueous systems co-catalytic effects were widely discussed opening the possibility of lowering the over potential of the CO2 reduction by molecular activations mechanism.[18]
In addition to the mechanistic understanding, a deeper knowledge of electrode material and its behavior according to corrosion processes and its deactivation is required. We therefore decided to focus on material characterization techniques which provide the ability to analyze structural and chemical changes under distinguished electrolysis stages.

sections.heading: 2.1. Results Derived with Solid Electrodes (Influence of the Electrolyte)
sections.text:
Initial experiments with polycrystalline Cu electrodes in noncorrosive 0.1 m KHCO3 electrolytes were limited to only FE = 15% for ethylene at a partial current density of 3 mA cm−2. (For detailed results see Figures S1 and S2 in the Supporting Information.) The results of several repeated experiments with solid copper electrodes strongly differ from each other, because selectivity toward formation of hydrocarbons like ethylene, methane, and alcohols is very sensitive toward the surface morphology of the electrode and their catalytic active sites. Since halogen containing electrolytes like KBr, KCl have been identified as beneficial in context of ethylene selectivity,[17] experiments were performed in which mainly KBr and mixtures between KBr and Br2 were used in order to reproduce these observations. Br2 was added because we observed its diffusion into the cathode chamber, even when separation membranes were used. The results with a 0.1 m KBr catholyte appeared slightly advantageous toward KHCO3, because higher current densities have been achieved and the CO production was slightly decreased, while the hydrogen evolution is suppressed at low potentials. At higher potentials the methane production in KBr is slightly lower than it was observed with KHCO3. By using a highly concentrated KBr solution (3 m) the cell potential could be reduced even further due to the high conductivity of 3 m KBr. However, in this experiment it was observed that the Br− ions can pass through the Nafion membrane and migrate into the anolyte which finally resulted in a bromine evolution in the anode compartment. In addition a blue coloration of the catholyte appeared after about 30 min of electrolysis time. The poorly soluble blue solid was formed in all experiments with
halogene/halogenide containing electrolytes. Its formation originates from precipitation of dissolved copper ions in an alkaline environment. The material was identified by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) as azurite (Cu3(CO3)2(OH2). The electrode itself became black during the experiment. This experiment showed an increased FE for ethylen e = 20%, and in turn the typical methane formation (FE = 40%) which was previously observed in 0.1 m KHCO3 (Figure S2, Supporting Information), could be almost completely suppressed.
Obviously, high concentrations of halide ions led to an enhanced corrosion of the Cu electrode accompanied by the formation of free Cu2+ ions in the solution. A part of the dissolved Cu2+ was then reduced at the negatively charged electrode which caused the formation of nanoparticular deposits. In order to enhance the corrosion effect and the associated increase in ethylene selectivity, the catholyte was deliberately modified by the addition of bromine (c = 0.2 mol L−1) (used as oxidizing agent). The corresponding electrochemical results are shown in Figure 1.
The analysis of the electrode surface by SEM before the electrolysis and after 150 min operation time is illustrated in Figure 2, indicating a significant change of the electrode surface by the addition of bromine.

The phase composition of these needle-like dendrites was analyzed by grazing incidence X-ray diffraction (GIXRD) measurements. CuBr and Cu2O were detected as main phases. An identification of copper-(0)-nanodeposits was not possible due to strong overlapping reflections of the copper substrate. From the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis of the electrode surface after 150 min electrolysis time one can conclude that copper-(I)-species and residuals of KBr are present at the surface of the dendritic structures. Reference corrosion experiments using other oxidizing agents such as oxygen and peroxo disulfate showed very similar results. The addition of such strong oxidizing agents, especially in acidic solution, finally led to morphological changes of the copper surface. Nano deposits were formed by copper dissolution and simultaneous redeposition. The dendritic growth was controlled by the intensity of the developing hydrogen bubbles during the deposition phase. This method is well-known in the literature and can be utilized for the deposition of the ethylene-selective Cu-deposits under high overpotential.[19] Under presence of a halide or halogen-containing electrolyte (0.1 m KBr + Br2) traces of CuBr were identified in the deposits. From Ogura’s work one can conclude that CuBr species are required for the selective formation of ethylene.[6,17,20] In order to demonstrate this assumption, polycrystalline Cu-sheets with 1 cm2 area were anodically brominated in a 3 m KBr electrolyte with 10 C of charge. The SEM image of the CuBr deposited electrode before and after electrolysis is illustrated in Figure 3. The corresponding X-ray photoelectron (XP) spectra of CuBr-film before and after the electrolysis clearly indicate chemical changes (Figure S3, Supporting Information).
After electrolysis in 0.1 m KHCO3, a nearly complete morphological and chemical change of the dense CuBr layer was observed. The XP spectra of the surface after electrolysis indicated the additional formation of Cu0 and a simultaneous decrease of the CuBr species represented by the Br 3d5/2 (69.2 eV) and Cu 3p3/2 (75 eV) signals (see Figure S3 in the Supporting
Information). The electrode also colored black after the electrolysis experiment. A Faradaic efficiency of 20% was obtained for ethylene. The measurements suggest that CuBr itself is not essential for the formation of ethylene, because it is obviously reduced under electrolysis conditions to Cu. However, intermediately formed CuBr species cannot be ruled out. Therefore, we would like to point out the use of operando-spectroscopic studies for clarification.
To summarize, halogens or halides containing electrolytes led preferably in an acidic pH environment to Cu electrode corrosion (especially if no negative potential is present or even under OCP). These observations were also in line with prior corrosion studies of copper in halogene containing media.[21,22] The formation of poorly soluble azurite and malachite could be observed. However, this observation was considered with a direct catalytic function or especially important for ethylene selectivity. In order to confirm the importance of the deposited in situ Cu nanostructures and to study their morphology and chemical composition closer, depositions were specifically carried out by the addition of Cu2+ containing salt as CuSO4 into the electrolyte solution under acidic pH conditions in the absence of halogens.

sections.heading: 2.2. In Situ Deposition of Cu Nano Structures by Adding CuSO4
sections.text:
In order to demonstrate the positive catalytic effect of the Cu nano deposits, the following experiments were conducted without the addition of halogenide or halogene containing electrolytes in order to prevent any further Cu-dissolution by halogen-mediated corrosion. For in situ deposition a 0.1 m K2SO4 solution containing 0.01 m CuSO4 was used as electrolyte. After CO2 saturation the electrolyte was leveled to a defined initial pH state of 2–3 by the addition of sulfuric acid prior to the deposition of Cu. A solid 1 cm2 large silver plate (Ag 99.999%) was used as electrode substrate to enable a further characterization of the phase composition by GIXRD (without Cu substrate interference). The electrochemical deposition of Cu nanostructures was carried out at −1.55 V versus Ag/AgCl for 10 min prior to the electrochemical characterization series. During this deposition phase, the pH increased rapidly from 3.0 to 5.5 and finally reached its maximum at 8.5 after 150 min electrolysis time. This effect could be explained by carbonate buffer formation under local basic cathode conditions. The silver electrode was plated instantly with a black layer and a slight particle detachment was observed. The modified electrode yielded a maximum of ethylene FE of 30%. Surprisingly, the silver-specific formation of CO was completely suppressed by the deposition of Cu-deposits. The used electrode was rinsed with degassed dest. water and rapidly dried in vacuum prior to further characterization. The powder pattern of the electrode surface after electrolysis is illustrated in Figure 4. The powder pattern indicated the presence Cu2O in cuprite modification as the main phase. It is noteworthy that the corresponding Cu-reflections provide evidence for the formation of Cu nano deposits. From the present results we concluded that the observed dendritic structures mainly consist of Cu and Cu2O. The SEM images show dendritic structures with a layer thickness of ≈20 µm which mainly consist of cuprite and copper.

Beside the main phases Cu2O and Cu, K2SO4 residuals were detected in minor proportions which originated from the employed electrolyte. The in situ deposition of Cu in an acidic pH environment could astonishingly suppress the formation of CO which one would expect from the silver electrode substrate. This fact leads us to conclude that the observed Cu nanodeposits obviously formed the catalytically active layer which enables the selective formation of ethylene. To closer investigate the long-term stability of the in situ deposited catalyst, constant potential experiments were conducted over a time period of 150 min. The optimized working potential of the cathode was located in a voltage range experiments between (−1.5 and −1.55 V) versus Ag/AgCl. From the electrochemical characterization at constant potential, a trend was observed, which followed a continuous decrease in ethylene selectivity after about 50 min electrolysis time. This trend correlates simultaneously with a gradual increase in the FE for H2. Apparently, undesirable aging of the initially formed selective catalyst dendrites was observed after 150 min electrolysis time. The coarsening of the fine structures and the formation of new catalytic centers having a lower hydrogen over potential lead preferably to the formation of hydrogen. For a more detailed analysis, two Cu electrodes were coated in situ and analyzed directly after deposition and after 150 min electrolysis time. Both electrodes were characterized by SEM and TEM (see Figure 5). Beside the morphological characterization, the chemical characterization was carried out by selected area electron diffraction measurements (SAD). The SEM image of the electrode surface after in situ Cu deposition shows a network of connected needle-like dendrites. The SEM image of the electrode surface which was analyzed after 150 min electrolysis time, however, shows a marked coarsening of the needle-like deposits beside the formation of flower like structures. In order to get more information about the morphology of the active centers and to characterize the phases, high-resolution TEM measurements were performed on both electrodes. The figures show a similar trend compared to the SEM photographs. The fine acicular (4–5 nm in shape) structure of the specimen after deposition coarsen

during electrolysis. Apparently the reason for this effect seems to lie in local sintering or dissolution/re-deposition processes of copper. The observed changes in morphology correlate directly with the observed decrease in ethylene selectivity. The presence of poorly soluble malachite and azurite salts remaining in the electrolyte after in situ deposition were not observed. Electron diffraction measurements have clearly demonstrated that the fine needles and also the coarser structures on the electrodes mainly consist of Cu and Cu2O. The role of Cu2O species and their stability or presence under electrolysis conditions remains unclear. However it has
been reported by Ren et al. that Cu2O was rapidly reduced to metallic copper within the first 200 s during CO2 electrolysis on Cu2O films.[23] The effect was supported by the disappearance of the characteristic Cu2O bands at ν = 526, and ν = 624 cm−1 during operando Raman Spectroscopy. The removal of the cathodic potential led to a rapid re-oxidation indicated by the appearance of Cu2O Raman bands at ν = 147, ν = 520, and ν = 624 cm−1. Le et al. published similar results obtained by near edge X-ray absorption fine structure (NEXAFS) experiments, where the characteristic Cu2O shoulder at 933.3 eV was monitored before and after electro reduction of CO2. The authors observed an decrease of the characteristic Cu2O band after electrolysis which was attributed to the reduction to metallic copper.[24] The observations led us suggest that Cu+-species are reduced to metallic copper but it is further unclear if Cu+ can at least exist in low concentrations or as intermediates during catalysis. It seems reasonable to assume that the change of oxidation state between Cu/Cu+ might occupy an essential role within the mechanism of the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2. Upon that Cu+-species are known to form strong π-complexes with CO or ethylene which finally should stabilize such intermediates/products.[25]

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Impurities/Chemical Composition of the In Situ Deposited Layers
sections.text:
The electro catalytic reduction of CO2 to ethylene is known to be relatively sensitive toward surface impurities of group eight transition metals. Traces of these impurities such as iron or nickel could drastically decrease the ethylene selectivity even in the sub-ppm range. The impurities preferably form hydrogen and the formation of ethylene retards. It is known that carbon impurities might also be associated with an increased formation of hydrogen.[26,27] In order to identify relevant contaminants, energy dispersive Xray spectroscopy (EDX) element mapping studies and XPS measurements were carried out (see Figure S4 in the Supporting Information.) The evaluation of the XP survey spectra of the electrode surfaces after coating and after 150 min electrolysis time leads to the conclusion that both electrodes contain carbon species beside small amounts of impurities of Ga and Zn. Both electrodes contain electrolyte residues with significant amounts of chlorides. The electrode operated 150 min furthermore shows deposits of Cu2+ species due to
the formation of sparingly soluble malachite and azurite at pH values >5.6. For identification of the site-specific contamination level of the surfaces, spatially resolved element mappings were conducted on significant and representative particles by scanning transmission electron microscop (STEM) EDX illustrated in Figure 6.
By comparing the analysis results of the electrode after coating and after 150 min electrolysis time no systematic trend could be derived for the location of impurities. The XPS measurement results show clear similarities to the element mapping methods (STEM/EDX). Thus, it can be assumed that the impurities of Ga, Zn, and chloride must originate from the electrolyte. An enrichment effect of contaminations by the electrolysis itself could not be clearly identified. Both samples contain as already confirmed by XPS measurements, significant amounts of carbon impurities. By the use of the energy filtered transmission electron microscopy (EF-TEM) technique we were able to examine the element distributions of Cu, O, and C in the deposited dendrites in more detail in order to determine the local element distribution within the fine structure.
The EF-TEM elemental mapping analysis of the sample operated 150 min clearly show that the dendrites itself mainly consist of Cu and oxides (Figure 7). Beside these observations carbon based impurities were directly located onto the surface of the dendrites in two independent dendrite regions. The respective deposits were also detected in the same way on an electrode sample immediately after the coating. The corresponding carbon deposits can therefore not be directly considered to explain the observed decrease in selectivity of ethylene after 50 min electrolysis time. Furthermore, it could not be clearly distinguished whether these carbon-containing adsorbates consists of (CO, C2H4, HCOO−, CO32−) or elemental carbon.

sections.heading: 2.3. In Situ Deposition of Cu Nano Structures on a Carbon Fiber Gas Diffusion Layer (GDL) (Flow Cell Setup)
sections.text:
Gas diffusion electrodes are commonly used in technical applications to counteract the limitations of the low space time yield and low space velocity obtained in processes with solid metal electrodes. For this reason, the use of gas diffusion electrodes is essential to intensify the mass transport of CO2 to the active sites near the electrode surface, since the CO2 solubility in

water is limited to 0.04 mol L−1 at T = 20 °C and ambient pressure.[28,29] The skeletal structure of the electrode consists mainly of a microporous layer which contains hydrophobic pores and channels for gas transport. The catalyst containing layer (CL) has strong hydrophilic properties which are mainly determined by the catalyst itself. The catalyst should furthermore be highly electrical conductive to ensure a uniform potential and current distribution. The herein presented gas diffusion electrode (GDE) is based on a commercially available Freudenberg C2 GDL which consists of polytetrafluoroethylene-bonded carbon fiber tissue (backbone) with a microporous PTFE bonded activated carbon layer. The catalyst was directly in situ deposited by the aforementioned technique to obtain the highly desired dendritic ethylene selective structure. The catalyst loading was determined to be 1 mg (in total) and 0.3 mg cm−2 (by area). No particle detachment was observed during the experiment. The electrochemical characterization of the electrode was performed in a flow cell setup equipped with a Nafion 117 membrane as separator. The cell design further allows the possibility to fumigate the electrode directly with CO2 from behind to overcome mass transport limitations. An active geometric surface area of 3.3 cm2 was used (for further details see the experimental section.) Figure 8 illustrates the time dependent Faradaic efficiencies of quantified products obtained by the electrochemical characterization of the in situ prepared electrode. During the deposition process in acidic medium (pH 2.5), a Faradaic efficiency of about 35% for methane was observed within the first 10 min, which then rapidly decreased. The initial evolution of methane originates from an increase of the working electrode potential more negative than (−2 V) during deposition at constant current. Ethylene was identified as the main product with a FE of 57% within a time range between 30 and 90 min. The total calculated Faradaic efficiency of gaseous products was only around 80% which originates from the formation of liquid products. 1H NMR measurements of the catholyte samples proved the formation of ethanol (main liquid product) and n-propanol beside acetate and formate (see Figure S7 in the Supporting Information.) In respect to the total delivered electrical charge and the amount of the liquid products, a total Faraday efficiency of nearly 100% could be calculated.[30] The time-dependent experiment at constant current showed an undesirable decrease in ethylene selectivity as it has already been observed in previous experiments with solid electrodes. The large surface area and the high porosity of the prepared electrode enabled high conversion rates per weight and hours (1020 mol kg cat−1 h−1) and per seconds and area (8.58 × 10−4 mol s−1 m−2). The determination of reaction rates could be found in Figure S9 in the Supporting Information.
A current density of 170 mA cm−2 was achieved, which is about one order of magnitude higher than the results obtained for a solid copper substrate. The originally observed diffusion limitation at solid copper electrodes is therefore not the cause of the decrease in the ethylene selectivity of the catalyst. The measurement was stopped after 150 min electrolysis time. Long time experiments were not performed since the electrolyte system was separated by electro osmosis after prolonged time and the cell voltage rose drastically. Further investigations on system optimization are required to enable longtime testing which was not the focus of this work. Reproducibility measurements were performed which indicated only slight measurement deviations of the obtained ethylene

sections.heading: 3. Conclusion
sections.text: Cu nanodendrites were obtained during an in situ electro deposition in acidic medium (pH = 2.5) under high over potential (<-2 V vs Ag/AgCl). The desired nanoscaled structures exhibit increased selectivity toward the formation of ethylene. Furthermore, the performance of the material is independent of the substrate. During electrolysis structural changes of the active layer were observed. Apparently local sintering and oxidation processes occurred, which contribute to the coarsening of the fine structures. The obtained experimental results strongly provide evidence for a structural degradation of the initially formed active species and finally resulted in a loss of the required high index facets containing low coordinated sites which might be responsible for the formation of ethylene.[31] The demonstrated formation of carbon adsorbates onto the Cu deposits themselves could be ruled out as the root course of the decrease in ethylene selectivity, as they were already present after catalyst deposition. Beside ethylene, ethanol, and n-propanol were observed as the main liquid phase products.

sections.heading: 4. Experimental Section
sections.text:
All experiments were conducted by presaturating the electrolyte with CO2 for 10 min before the experiment was started. All materials were used without further purification.
The experiments with solid polycrystalline electrode materials were performed in a two compartment H-Type electrolysis cell (5 mL) equipped with a cation exchange membrane (Nafion N117). Ag and Cu sheets (purity 99.999%) were cut into electrodes of 1 cm2 geometric area and grinded with SiC paper (grit 1000), prior to etching in 6 m HNO3 (for Ag) and (NH4)2 S2O8 (for Cu) at T = 60 °C. Pt sheet electrodes were used as anode. The electrochemical characterization was carried out under potentiostatic conditions by potential variation and at constant potential. A flow cell was used as the corresponding manifold for gas diffusion electrode characterization. The active electrode area was limited to 3.3 cm2 by using a copper frame as current collector. The GDE was prepared by copper in situ deposition of copper onto a Freudenberg C2 GDL from a 0.01 m CuSO4 (from CuSO4·5H2O 99.999% Aldrich) containing electrolyte at pH = 2.5 during the electrolysis. (The initial pH value) of the solution was adjusted by the addition of a 1 m H2SO4 (99.999% Aldrich) to a value of pH = 2.5. A solid IrOx coated Ti electrode was used as counter electrode. The CO2 reduction was carried out under constant current (170 mA cm−2) to maintain stable electrolysis conditions. 0.1 m KBr (99.0% Alfa Aesar) was used as catholyte (100 mL) and 1 m KHCO3 (>99.7% Alfa Aesar) as anolyte (100 mL). The electrolyte flow was controlled by an eight channel peristaltic pump at a flow rate of 100 mL min−1. CO2 gas (4.8 Linde) was used without further purification and continuously supplied at a constant flow rate of 50 mL min−1 at atmospheric pressure. The gas samples were taken from the effluent of the electrolytic cell every 10 min by using gas sample bags and analyzed by gas chromatograph. All gas samples were measured with a Thermo Scientific Trace 1310 gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with two thermal conductivity detector (TCD) channels. For separation of hydrocarbons a micropacked GC column (shin carbon) with He as carrier was used. The determination of H2 was performed on a packed molsieve column using Ar as carrier. All electrolysis experiments were conducted using Metrohm Autolab potentiostat equipped with two voltage measurement (PX)-modules for additional potential measurements. All measurements
were performed without iR-drop compensation. In some experiments, the electrodes were further modified by the electrochemical deposition of CuBr by ex situ anodic oxidation of the copper electrode in a 3 m KBr solution. Ag/AgCl reference electrodes were used in all static H-type cell experiments.

Calculations have shown that the resulting additional capital costs for conversion plants are to be borne only by a corresponding material value chain. The electrochemical production of chemical substances such as valuable ethylene and alcohols based on the waste product CO2 is therefore preferable toward the production of fuels (methane), since these are in strong price competition to cheap natural gas. The commercialization of the electrochemical production of valuable chemical base products from CO2 strongly depends on the development of high performance electrocatalyst which could maintain high product selectivities at high current density. Former studies have demonstrated high Faradaic efficiencies (FEs) >90% for the production of formate at a high current density of 200 mA cm−2 by the use of gas diffusion electrodes (GDEs).[2,3] Moreover the Kenis group has recently published results for the electroreduction of CO2 toward ethylene at current densities up to 150 mA cm−2.[4] The development of Cu-based electro catalysts for the electrochemical conversion of CO2 was pursued since the 1970s and has been specially dominated by the works of Hori and Ogura.[5,6] The obtained product spectrum is mainly determined by the copper catalyst morphology and could generally be divided into gaseous products (CH4, C2H4, CO, H2) and liquid phase products like ethanol, n-propanol, formate, ethylene glycol, allylic alcohol, and acetate.[7–10] More over halogens in the electrolyte seem to increase the selectivity of the process toward ethylene. Nano structured catalysts such as Cu2O/ZnO have been identified by Irabien and co-workers to be capable of reducing CO2 toward methanol. The maximum CO2 conversion efficiency to liquidphase products was identified to be 54.8% and 31.4% for Cu2O and Cu2O/ZnO-based electrodes. Degradation effects of the material were found.[11,12] In their recent work, this group investigated in developing electrodes based on porous metal organic catalysts (HKUST-1, CuAdeAce, CuDTA, and CuZnDTA) for the electroreduction of CO2 toward alcohols.[13] Studies with single crystal Cu-electrodes have shown that the introduction of step sites to the Cu (100) basal plane leads to remarkably enhanced formation of C2H4. The product selectivity varied with the crystal orientation. The electro catalytic activity of C2H4 formation on Cu(S)-[n(100) × (111)] could further be activated by introduction of a certain amounts of step atoms. Crystal orientations In situ deposited copper nanodendrites are herein proven to be a highly selective electrocatalyst which is capable of reducing CO2 to ethylene by reaching a Faradaic efficiency of 57% at a current density of 170 mA cm−2. It is found that the desired structures are formed in situ under acidic pH conditions at high electrode potentials more negative than −2 V versus Ag/AgCl. Detailed investigations on the preparation, characterization, and advancement of electrode materials and of the electrolyte have been performed. Catalyst degradation effects are intensively followed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) characterization methods and found to be a major root course for selectivity losses.
